results.title: London Underground Map
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Design Classic Series”.
Designed by Harry Beck in 1933, this diagrammatic map hangs on the walls of London’s 273 Underground train stations and in the Metropolitan Museum of Modern Art in New York. A masterpiece of graphic design, it has become a symbol of London all over the world.

results.title: London to Brighton in four minutes
results.brief_description: By use of timelapse photography, this film gives an impression of travel by train at approximately the speed of sound. Photographed at two frames per second (instead of the normal twenty four) from the train driver’s cabin, every foot of the rail track is seen. Whereas the journey from London to Brighton takes an hour at an average speed of 65 miles per hour, this unusual journey takes four minutes at an average speed of 800 miles per hour.

results.title: London terminus
results.brief_description: From London a vast national railway system radiates: at the railway terminus in London, 1,704 trains enter and leave the station every day. Millions of urban workers depend entirely on the railway system for their daily transport to and from central London, and, in addition, there are many expresses and goods trains which span the length and breadth of Great Britain. Music composed by Horace Somerville, played by London Symphony Orchestra under Muir Mathieson.

results.title: London scene
results.creator_credit: Frank Gardner and Central Office of Information
results.brief_description: A picture of life in London. Follows the course of a typical day: arrival of early-morning fruit and vegetables at Covent Garden; invasion of the City by a million workers from the suburbs; the parks of London, havens for office workers during lungh-time; diversity of shops and busy streets; the zoo; Crown Jewels in the Tower. After dark, the cry of “Time, gentlemen, please!” in the public hotels brings the day to a close.

results.title: London can take it!
results.creator_credit: Humphrey Jennings, Harry Watt and GPO Film Unit
results.brief_description: London life in the blitz is presented as ‘a series of contrasts between the ordinary and the extraordinary, the casual and the tense, beauty and destruction, stillness and action, silence and noise, light and dark’. This is surrealism based not on symbolic representation of the subconscious but on images of everyday, images transformed by exceptional circumstances of war. These images are public not private. Their power is entirely cultural and social. The commentary by American correspondent Quentin Reynolds interacts in quite a complex way with the images. Primarily intended for North American audiences, a shorter five minute adaptation called Britain Can Take It was screened very successfully in British cinemas and was something of a breakthrough for British documentary.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Humphrey Jennings, Harry Watt and GPO Film Unit

results.title: London 1942
results.creator_credit: Ken Annakin, Ralph Keene, Verity Films and Greenpark Productions
results.brief_description: A Picture of Wartime London: “A picture of London in 1942 showing a cheerful though bomb-scarred city. The streets are full of British and Allied servicemen. In the parks there are allotments; tomatoes grow on roof tops. The film shows Londoners in the Home Guard and Civil Defence. It ends with scenes of London after dark.” (Source: Films of Britain - British Council Film Department Catalogue - 1942-1943)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ken Annakin, Ralph Keene, Verity Films and Greenpark Productions

results.title: London's water supply
results.creator_credit: Metropolitan Water Board and World Wide Pictures
results.brief_description: Illustrates how the Board supplies some six and a half million people in and around London with water for all their needs - a daily consumption of 380 million gallons. Shows where the water sources are, water treatment, pumping, quality control and distribution, waste detection and administration.

results.title: London's country
results.creator_credit: Syd Sharples, Harold Lowenstein, Ian Ferguson, Edgar H. Anstey and British Transport Films
results.brief_description: Presents a world of wildlife and flowers and scenic beauty - where people can enjoy yachting on the Thames, or archery at Sevenoaks; riding at Knole Park, or morris-dancing at Westerham; walking over the hills near Newlands Corner, or cricket on the green at Cookham; where they can admire historic buildings - Windsor Castle, Canterbury Cathedral, Farnham Keep, the Dickens houses at Rochester, the Roman ruins at Verulamium.
